posts.name: Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked:
A big concept I ran into during my first year of FRC programming is about the two main ways teams approach tuning subsystems, especially when it comes to things like feedforward values for elevators, arms, drivetrains, etc.

One option is to just try different values until something works. The other is to break out the physics and calculate everything based on known specs. Both work, but they each come with tradeoffs.

The Empirical Route  
This is the trial-and-error approach. You give the mechanism some voltage, see what holds it in place or gets it moving, and record that as your constant. It’s fast, intuitive, and based on what actually happens on the robot. Some examples include manually tuning kG by finding the voltage that holds an elevator in place running test paths to tune kS, kV, kA adjusting PID gains by feel or through testing. It works well when you’re short on time or don’t have all your numbers nailed down, but it can take longer to retune if you change something like a gear ratio, motor, or weight.

The Calculated Route  
This is where you model the system on paper before you even power it on. You figure out the force needed to counter gravity, convert that to motor torque, then voltage using motor specs. Ideally, you end up with constants that are close to correct from the start. Some tools that help here include CAD mass properties motor curves (from the REV/CTRE data sheets) gear ratios and mechanism geometry FRC Characterization (sysid). This method can scale better as your design changes, and it helps new students learn the “why” behind the numbers. But if your model is off—for wrong mass underestimated friction; the results can be pretty far from what you actually need.

What I’m Wondering  
Curious what other teams do here. A few questions to kick things off: Do you start with calculations or go straight to testing on the robot? How much do you rely on modeling vs. trial and error? Do you recalculate your constants every time the design changes? How well do your calculated constants usually match what ends up working? Have you changed your approach over time as your team got more experience? How do you help new students understand both sides of this?

Would love to hear what’s worked for you whether you mostly test things out on the robot or try to get close with math first.

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked: bookmarking this thread
Teams may reconsider their approach when new tools emerge to support theoretical tuning as they gain more experience with it.

posts.name: Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked: Yeah, I tried to use Recalc for tuning my elevator PID constants, but there seems to be a loss in all the variables that go into mechanical applications. To me it seems like there would have to be thousands of variables for these kinds of tools to be truly accurate.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: Most of what we’ve done this year involved using calculated constants via recalc to obtain approximate estimates, followed by manual tuning to achieve the desired system behavior. Nearly all our tuning constants were adjusted manually during the season. Sysid has been effective for drive motors, but manual tuning yields better results for steer motors.

There isn’t anything unfortunately. I’m working on a method to enable you to simulate and test theoretical models on a webpage, similar to wpilib sim found at docs.wpilib.org and linked to reca.lc, utilizing a webform to generate input parameters for subsystem codes.

posts.name: Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked: Are system identification techniques employed primarily only for drive trains? While I’ve traditionally considered system characterization as an effective method for tuning parameters, I’ve never encountered its implementation in systems like arms or elevators.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: No, just for the drivetrain.

posts.name: Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked: That seems wonderful. I like the idea of integrating everything instead of having fifty different tools. It would be nice—even though it's very time-consuming—to have software that uses CAD models to simulate things so the whole mechanism can be tested. It could also help with stress analysis.

posts.name: Lauchlin
posts.cooked:
The text provided can be cleaned up while preserving its original meaning. Here's how: Original Text: ```

Depends on the system really. But using math to pick a good starting point for numbers and then tuning empirically from there is a good approach.

It’s fairly common to be retuning these robots all season long as they wear in or are modified. (Physically or in code)

``` Cleaned Up Text: ``` Using math to select an appropriate starting point for figures and then fine-tuning empirically is generally effective. Regularly adjusting robots throughout the season due to wear or modifications (either physically or via code) is customary. ```

posts.name: Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked: This is what I’m seeing from many teams. Previously, when I was first tuning our 2025 robot, Nessie, I used 0.0005, continuously multiplied by 10 until I received feedback. Then, of course, I tuned it to correct the feedback, but next year, I’ll think about re-calculation.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: FRC Characterization (sysid) is a valuable tool for both empirical tuning and feedback analysis, helping determine optimal gains. Calculating kV typically works well with gear ratios, except in cases with significant viscous friction, such as flywheels, where alternative methods may be needed. Determining kS often requires empirical estimation. While kG is generally easy to estimate, especially for mechanisms like elevators where voltage ranges can provide precise values, its utility diminishes compared to other parameters. For elevators, kA is derived from kG divided by gravity. Empirical methods, including increasing proportional gains until oscillation occurs, offer reliable feedback control strategies. Using tools like the sysid analyzer provides a practical starting point for estimating proportional and derivative gains, enhancing system performance effectively.

posts.name: Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked: In your opinion, how important is it to tune all of these? Last year, I used position voltage on our elevator with only P & D, which worked pretty well and was very snappy for what I needed. Do you think that putting into tuning these is worth how much time and wear reduction you gain?

I support calculating your constants whenever possible as when done correctly, you can tune your mechanisms very quickly and maximize the performance out of them. The absolute best thing about designing controllers by math/simulation is that you can design them and understand the system behavior before you even have a robot, and use those results to influence the robot design. The other benefits are nice and I use simulations before, during, and after building the robot, but the ability for it to influence your design decisions is the most important benefit by a lot.

If the mass significantly changes, you will usually have to re-tune for the new system inertia and re-tune the feedback gains. The rest of the system properties should stay the same however. Some tools that help here are CAD mass properties, motor curves from REV/CTRE data sheets, gear ratios and mechanism geometry, FRC characterization (sysid), and kV should always be calculated as it is overwhelmingly influenced by the motor’s back-emf. While kA can be calculated using J/(kt*ratio), it must be obtained through sysID because the motor inertia needs to be accounted for as it can range from very significant to overshadowing in terms of system dynamics.

Feedback gains however should be tuned in simulation or the robot. While there are techniques to calculate when with math, the math relies on idealized models that don’t work in the not so pretty world. So you either have to simulate the not-so-pretty world (doable) or tune on the physical robot. One more very important thing is that feedback and feedforward constants have both units and a frame of reference and you need to know what these are when mathing them out. kP of 1000 is unhelpful because... [units explanation].

Unless you are trying to gain the last few ms of performance out of a mechanism or are working with complicated mechanisms such as a double-jointed arm, the model doesn’t need to be 100% perfect to have good performance due to feedback. Recalcs’s sim is not good due to not simulating deceleration which is extremely important. AMB will find the ratio better due to simulating decel, but a custom simulation will get you much better results because you can make sure you simulate all relevant dynamics. These tools also don’t work if the robot is mechanically bad (very poor stiffness, backlash, non-constant friction…) or is non-linear (linkages are the big offender mainly), do designing mechanisms that are stiff and do what they are told should be the highest priority.

I’ve found you only need 9 constants to have your sim accurately simulate reality. You need inertia, viscous damping, dry friction, external forces, motor effective armature resistance, back-emf constant, torque constant (not quite equal to back-emf constant), pure time delay, and sampling frequency. The last two are extremely important when simulating controllers as they are typically the reason controllers go unstable and severely limit the amount of derivative gain you can apply and can make you prefer a slightly lower ratio than would be optimal in a perfect world.

Swerve is annoying because the friction is both super non-linear and just difficult (practically impossible) to model, which is very significant on the steering motors. I wouldn’t ever recommend using sims or math on these types of mechanisms as its not designed to handle these types of non-linearities.

posts.name: Justin Tervay
posts.cooked: Author of Recalc here. I don’t actually use any of the gains feature on the site, although they’re useful for others. My teams have historically simply empirically tuned everything. Doesn’t take very long once you do it a few times. If we lose a match simply because our elevator’s time to goal is only 0.7sec instead of 0.5sec, I’m a happy guy. We got other things to spend time on.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
To me, it seems like these kinds of tools would require thousands of variables to be truly accurate.  
But wait, DC motors are very predictable and linear systems.

posts.name: Kegan Cherry
posts.cooked: What's the scalability here? For instance, last year I solo-programmed and tested our robot. We were under such a tight schedule that it seemed impractical to conduct all these simulations. Put another way, when is it reasonable to allocate time to simulate rather than running empirical tests on the team?

You must prepare the simulation stack beforehand since it requires several months to create it properly. The challenging aspects involve both designing the simulator initially and learning its usage effectively. Afterward, once the simulation is operational, achieving positive outcomes becomes relatively quick.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: While tuning your mechanism, focus on achieving your goals efficiently. These goals likely involve reaching your target quickly and accurately while minimizing the time spent on tuning. If PositionVoltage combined with kP and kD settings suffices your needs and meets these objectives, there’s no reason to complicate things further. Motion Magic offers enhanced flexibility in adjusting your feedback gains (P and D), potentially reducing the effort required to find precise values. Some teams prefer using Motion Magic alongside only kV and kP settings. However, others have reported improved performance, such as an elevator, by switching to Motion Magic from PositionVoltage control.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Lots of good technical opinions here. I don’t think I’d have much to add. Where I wear my mentor hat is thinking about team goals. Do you just need your mechanism to function adequately so you can move on to other goals, or does your team value the time and effort spent understanding why something works? Guess-and-check methods usually take longer to become reliable. They require no upfront investment to create accurate software simulations, correctly place weights in CAD, or ensure consistent unit handling across different parts of the system. However, altering many aspects often means repeating the entire tuning process. On the other hand, calculated gains offer a quicker way to adjust settings but come with higher initial setup demands and emphasize better design practices. Time is your most valuable resource. Discuss with your team how and where to allocate their time on such matters—this could shape the technical direction they choose.
